ORDER 1. The grievance projected in this petition relates to the subject(s) covered by Section 14 of the Central administrative Tribunals act, 1985 (CaT act). The jurisdiction to hear this petition as a Court of first instance, therefore, lies with the Central presently holding sittings at Jammu, retaining a soft copy thereof. 3. The petitioner is aggrieved by the fact that on 13.08.2018, the petitioner had taken her daughter to Lal Bahadur Shastri Hospital to get the third injection for a dog bite injury that she had previously. Upon reaching the hospital, the petitioner left her daughter in a queue in the waiting area outside the doctor's room and left her briefly to complete some formalities. When the petitioner returned to the waiting area, her daughter was nowhere to be found. Petitioner immediately
CNR : DLHC012315312018 | Date of registration : 23-08-2018 | Decision Date : 10-11-2023 | Disposal Nature :
Court : High Court of Delhi

Judge : ,
put forth, however, there appears no infirmity even in the determination of the compensation already directed to be paid vide the impugned award.” 6. Even otherwise, the present appeal has been filed by the appellants after a gross delay of 1260 days. No satisfactory or explanation has been given as regards the delay in filing the present appeal. Judge : AMIT BANSAL
(hereinafter “Complainant”) impugning the order dated 15th February, 2023 passed by the learned Additional Sessions Judge (ASJ), Tis Hazari Courts, Delhi, whereby the summoning order dated 9th January, 2020 passed by the Metropolitan Magistrate (MM), Central, Tis Hazari Courts, Delhi, in a residing beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the ld. Trial Court. Therefore, the ld. Trial Court, ought to have conducted an inquiry u/s. 202 CrPC before arriving at a conclusion that there is sufficient ground to proceed against the accused. However, in the instant case, the said inquiry was was not required to ascertain the existence of a legally enforceable debt prior to the issuance of summons as that is a matter of trial. In this regard, reliance has been placed on the judgment of Shiv Kumar v. Ramavtar agarwal, (2020) 12 SCC 500. 7. Per contra, senior counsel appearing

CONFERENCING THIS DaY, CHIEF JUSTICE MaDE THE FOLLOWING: ORDER On 23rd November, 2020, the order of which breach is alleged has been stayed by a Division Bench of this Court in a writ appeal. Hence, as of today, there is no reason to proceed against the accused under the Contempt Courts act, 1971. In the event the order of which breach is alleged, is confirmed, and thereafter the same is not complied with, the complainant can always file a fresh contempt petition or apply for revival of this petition. 2. promotion within a stipulated time. Moot question involves if a promotion of employee can be withheld for indefinite period on the premises of pendency of vigilance proceeding over a period of decades. This Court considering such situation has already settled the position of law petitioner taking effect in the year 2014 has been kept in sealed cover only on the premises that a vigilance proceeding involving the petitioner is pending since 2004. For the settled position of law, this Court in disposal of the writ petition observes, petitioner cannot suffer for the

513
Judge :
position in law that a decree would be binding on any party which claims its right or title or interest, through the judgment debtor, as per the scheme of Order XXI CPC. The appellant being a dealer of HPCL, the decree is binding on him. 21. accordingly, the Judgment Debtor is directed to hand may be sought by HPCL/Decree Holders.” (Emphasis supplied) 4.1 He states that there has been a material subsequent development that in as much as the appeal i.e., RCa DJ 109/2019 filed by the appellant against the order dated 02.07.2019 passed by the Civil Judge has also been dismissed

Judge :
institutions which earn profit or engaged in trade. a Seven Judges Bench of Supreme Court in Bangalore Water Supply &amp; Sewerage Board v. a . Rajappa, (1978) 2 SCC 213 opined that definition of "Industry" is very wide. any systematic activity of employment or providing service is included in the of "Industry". Shri Sajid akhtar could not point out from evidence or otherwise that the nature of activity of petitioner is excluded from the definition of "Industry". Thus, in the opinion of this Court, the Labour Court has taken a plausible view which does not warrant any interference by
